text:
<@UJ4A0H534> nope, in this case it's total keyword rankings as reported by Ahrefs - I use it as a leading indicator of search traffic and a good way to work out which articles are gaining early traction in search/which aren't :slightly_smiling_face:

it's also a useful early-stage quantitative "win" to prove that your content is working, useful for sharing with customers/managers/etc while you wait for meaningful traffic to kick in

it's also a useful early-stage quantitative "win" to prove that your content is working, useful for sharing with customers/managers/etc while you wait for meaningful traffic to kick in

text: Ryan just said it all. If you want to use the tool, you need to be smart.

elements.text: Ryan just said it all. If you want to use the tool, you need to be smart.

text: A great example is that at my last agency (web design and marketing), we wanted to acquire more university marketers, so we wrote about that. Clearscope surfaced a bunch of words that seemed random, but by clicking on some of them and looking at the examples, they were studies and researchers that people working in edu marketing would know and reference. You can definitely find some gold, but don't treat it as keyword stuffing lest it become even more dangerous than the Yoast "green light."

Clearscope surfaced a bunch of words that seemed random, but by clicking on some of them and looking at the examples, they were studies and researchers that people working in edu marketing would know and reference. You can definitely find some gold, but don't treat it as keyword stuffing lest it become even more dangerous than the Yoast "green light."
